text: Answer Question 1 (Section A) and three questions from Section B.
Section A carries 33% of the marks and Section B carries 67% of the marks for this paper.
You have 3 hours (plus any pre-agreed individual adjustment) to answer this paper.
Where appropriate (e.g. for formulae, equations, or diagrams) you may hand write or draw on the Inspera paper provided.
<strong>Candidates should not copy and paste figures or content from any other documents.</strong

sub-instructions: Answer all parts (a-o) of Question 1. Each part carries equal marks. Suggested total time: not more than 1 hour. As a guideline, we suggest average answers should be approximately 100 words long.
content: Excluding DNA replication, summarise two ways in which the information encoded in DNA sequence can be "read" by cellular processes.
Summarise the advantages and disadvantages of electron microscopy, as compared with confocal light microscopy, for examining the structure and function of cells.
How many chiral carbons are present in the linear form of D-glucose, and does this change in the pyranose ring form? Why is stereochemistry important for the biochemistry of sugars?
How does the structural diversity of membrane lipids help cells to function as temperature varies?
Briefly outline the different mechanisms used by organisms to synthesize glutamate.
How does GluT4 regulate glycolysis in skeletal muscle and adipose tissue?
Describe the structure of glycogen and starch with reference to how the structure influences their roles as energy stores.
Why is it appropriate to refer to dominant and recessive phenotypes, but not to dominant and recessive alleles of genes? Illustrate your answer with one specific example.
What is a sigma factor and how is it important for the initiation of transcription in bacteria such as E. coli?.
Name, and briefly describe, the characteristics and functions of three types of RNA involved in the process of protein translation.
Briefly describe the main challenges in annotating eukaryotic genome sequence and how they can be overcome?
Name and briefly contrast two alternative cycles of viral replication.
Describe how the membrane phospholipid phosphatidylinositol 4,5- bisphosphate is used to generate second messengers.

How could you experimentally test if the sequence responsible for the localisation of an mRNA to the anterior of the developing Drosophila egg (oocyte) is in the 3â€™UTR (untranslated region)? Briefly describe one experiment and one control.
What sets the apico-basal axis of the plant embryo, for example in Arabidopsis?

sub-instructions: Answer three questions from the following nine. All questions carry equal marks. Suggested total time for this section: 2 hours
content: Macromolecular polymers enable enormous functional diversity of molecules to be created. Discuss this statement in relation to the properties of polysaccharides, nucleic acids and proteins, and give examples of how functional diversity is achieved in each.
Using examples, explain how ionic gradients are formed then dissipated across the cell membrane and why these processes are important for transport of small molecules across membranes.
With examples, outline the principles and main components that underpin the functioning of electron transfer chains in biology.
What role does the NAD+/NADH ratio play in regulating metabolism across the cell?
What were the main contributions of bacteriophages to progress in genetics and molecular biology during the second half of the 20th century?
Describe two common approaches for genome sequencing and discuss how the development of next generation sequencing approaches have impacted on our understanding of the human genome.
Describe the molecular events in the mitotic spindle checkpoint and what happens once the checkpoint has been satisfied to allow the cell cycle to progress.
How does fertilisation of a vertebrate egg by a sperm begin the development of the embryo and establish polarity.

Imagine you have been awarded unlimited funding to address the research question of "how do multicellular organism develop". However, you are restricted to the use of a single species for experimentation. Which species would you choose and why?
